results.title: The Samurai
results.creator_credit: Stafford Garner, Christopher McCullough, ABC-TV (Australia) and Australia-Japan Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Journey into Japan”.
This program examines the fate of the Samurai (warrior class) when Japan modernised at the turn of the century. Keith Adam shows the making of one of the countless popular movies which recreates the Samurai and their era and postulates that the Samurai live on not only in films but also in the business and industrial life of Japan. Narrated by Keith Adam.

results.title: The Long march south
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Barnes, Alan Bateman and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Journey into Thailand”.
This program describes the early history of the Thais. It tells how they came from China migrating over the mountains into Burma and Thailand and how they established their first kingdom by the fifteenth century and moved south when it was destroyed.

results.title: The Middle path
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Barnes, Alan Bateman and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Journey into Thailand”.
Keith Adam presents this program which offers a visit to the small market town of Chom Thong which provides a glimpse of life in a Buddhist monastery. It shows how the monastery and the monks play a vital part in the day-to-day life of the town.

results.title: William Delafield Cook interviewed by Deborah Hart...
results.creator_credit: Ian Stocks, Deborah Hart and Queensland Art Gallery
results.brief_description: This video provides a unique opportunity to explore the ideas and works of the Australian born artist William Delafield Cook. Produced in conjunction with the artist’s Retrospective at the Art Gallery of New South Wales, it covers the stylistic development of his art from the 1950’s to the present day. Delafield Cook lives and works both in England and Australia. Widely travelled, his art embodies an exceptionally diverse interest in art history, photography and films.

results.title: Conservation of artworks on paper
results.brief_description: Conservator of artworks on paper, Linda Black, demonstrates a series of conservation treatments used to slow or prevent future damage to artworks. Damage may have been caused by the use of inappropriate materials by the artist, undesirable procedures used by those preparing works for framing, or inadequate care of artworks through time. This video provides a “behind the scenes” look at the conservation operations at the Queensland Art Gallery.

results.title: Plagued. Episodes 1 & 2
results.creator_credit: Aviva Ziegler, Edward Goldwyn, Deanne Edwards, Janet Bell, Channel Four, Film Australia and Goldwyn Associates
results.brief_description: Conceived, written and narrated by award winning medical broadcaster, Dr. Norman Swan, this four part series investigates the relationship between history, destiny and disease. “The Origins of disease” investigates, through various case studies, including Korean haemorrhagic fever, shell shock, RSI and heart disease, how new diseases arise. We also discover that some are not diseases at all, but suffering made worse by factors as diverse as medical jargon and management style. “Epidemics: products of progress” takes up the theme that, ironically, throughout history, epidemics have been the results of so-called progress, and that despite medical technology, we are still vulnerable to old and new diseases, such as plague, cholera and AIDS which have the power to change the course of history.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Aviva Ziegler, Edward Goldwyn, Deanne Edwards, Janet Bell, Channel Four, Film Australia and Goldwyn Associates

results.title: The great dinosaur hunt
results.creator_credit: Brian Beaton, Location Equipment and Reel Images
results.brief_description: Western Australia is one of the oldest areas in the world and contains the earliest fossilised evidence of life walking on earth. This video follows Australian palaeontologist, Dr John Long, and the Dinosaur Club of the Museum of Western Australia (which includes hundreds of children) on their hunt for fossils, bones and footprints of the dinosaurs who once lived in that state. Computer and model animation are used to illustrate the dinosaurs whose relics have been unearthed, some of which are unknown in the Northern Hemisphere, which possibly suggests Australia was the last home of the dinosaurs before their extinction.

results.title: Brain sex. Episode 3
results.creator_credit: Ann Moir, Cheryl Knapp, Jonathan Harris, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, Discovery Channel, Primedia Productions, Primetime Television and Quality Time TV
results.brief_description: The final program in this series looks primarily at the sexual behaviour of men and women, how it differs, and each sex’s perceptions of the opposite sex’s motivation. It also looks at more differences between the female and male brains, particularly in relation to aging, and relationships with the opposite sex.

results.title: Child care: the management challenge for the 1990's
results.creator_credit: Mark Gould, Susan Lambert and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Twenty percent of all women workers have children under five and in 56% of families with dependent children, both parents work. Inadequate childcare facilities for these working parents can result in high absenteeism, low productivity and a high turnover rate. More and more companies are seeing the advantages to providing a carefully planned work-based childcare centre which ultimately benefits not just the employees, but the employer and the children. This video provides several examples of Sydney-based companies who have taken the initiative, including the Vacation Program run jointly by the NAB, ANZ, NML and CML, the Messengers Cottage Creche for the Esso/Lend Lease employees and the Flemington Market’s proposed childcare centre. The consensus appears to be a higher retention of skilled workers, particularly women, and an overall improvement in productivity.

results.title: The Professor's new clothes
results.creator_credit: Stephen Ramsey, Janet Bell, ABC-TV (Australia), Channel 4 and Film Australia
results.brief_description: ABC “Science Show” host, Robyn Williams, narrates this fascinating program on the ethics of scientific research and a recent case of major fraud involving internationally renowned geologist, Professor V. J. Gupta, of Punjab University. Gupta’s falsification of research spread over a 25 year period in 400 published papers. The fraud was unearthed due to the tireless detective work of Australian paleobiologist, Professor John Talent, of Macquarie University. The scandal generated by his findings resonated at a national level with the Indian government imposing a media ban in a cover-up attempt, but Talent’s perseverance meant the truth was finally made public.
